Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps L: Working for Kids: Building Skills

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through the NSF Innovation Corps for Learning Program, (I-Corps L), this project will develop ways to achieve more widespread use of an educational platform to improve the developmental trajectory of young children growing up in impoverished conditions. The Working for Kids: Building SkillsTM program consists of unique training materials that allow complex neuroscience-based principles to be understood and acted upon by parents and care givers and used to improve cognitive and related development of children. Working For Kids: Building SkillsTM includes a direct educational program, educational materials, and a train-the-trainer program to allow for broad dissemination of the Working for Kids: Building SkillsTM program. Through I-Corps L, the Working For Kids: Building SkillsTM program will determine approaches to better meet needs of potential users including parents, state child development programs, pediatricians and healthcare professionals, law enforcement, and foster care programs.

The Working For Kids: Building SkillsTM program aims to impact several critical areas of young children growing up in impoverished conditions. Working For Kids will increase participating community members' knowledge of brain development and growth in children. The program expects to improve the development of cognitive skills and social-emotional skills of young children (3-5 years of age) of the adults that complete the Working For Kids: Building SkillsTM program. Children of participants are expected to achieve improvements in the biological aspects of healthy brain development including quality of sleep and the production of stress chemicals in the body. Full development, testing, and broader use of the Working For Kids: Building SkillsTM program will advance knowledge of how to effectively educate the general public about brain development so this information can be used and applied to improve life trajectory of children.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project, Working For Kids: Building Skills, developed new educational materials and a new educational training program to teach adults living and working in stressed, impoverished communities about how to facilitate sturdy brain development in children, putting children in a better position to contribute meaningfully to the world. This is the first training program of its kind. Two aspects of this educational program differentiate it from other programs. 

First, the program teaches the basics of brain development, the general principle of how brain circuits are strengthened during the time they are “plastic” and are being built. Different brain circuits are being built at different times from the prenatal period to 25 years of age. Those receiving Working For Kids training learn that brain circuits can be strengthened by use during the time they are in their “plastic period”.  There are many educational programs that have been developed to teach specific skills (e.g., reading, math skills, social-emotional development), but there are not programs that teach the general principles of brain development that can be used to strengthen any skill. For example, once adults learn that the brain circuits underlying reading skills are “plastic” for the first seven years of life, they know that using many different ways to have a child be involved in reading and interested in reading and reading all the time will strengthen brain pathways for reading, that the child will have for the rest of their life. They learn to tailor the methods they try to engage the child in each activity to the individual child. In communities where there is little money available for special programs, this knowledge is extremely valuable because it can help tremendously with all developmental skills, as long as adults know at what age to focus on what skills, and they tailor the strategies for engaging children to the individual child.

The second aspect of the Working For Kids: Building Skills educational program that sets it apart is that it can be understood by people with a relatively low educational level and poor reading skills. All of the learning activities involve hands-on manipulation of educational materials and reading at about the 3rdgrade level. Even for the games and activities no special materials are needed so these games can generally be performed by children and adults in their home setting without having to buy additional materials. Thus, this program is accessible to those living in stressed and impoverished communities.

We believe the long-term impact will be that adults receiving Working For Kids training will be able to work with children to better prepare them with school readiness skills which will allow them to become more productive adults and more effective in parenting themselves. We also think such children will be less likely to interface with the justice system as they grow up and that over the course of their lifetimes they will have fewer long-term chronic health problems (including less obesity, mental illness, addition, heart disease). The development of Working For Kids Building Skills LLC is making these educational materials and train-the-trainer programs available at low cost, such that they can be widely disseminated and have the greatest impact possible in stressed, impoverished communities.
